segment.source: Learn how to store and retrieve local, roaming, and temporary app data.
segment.target: Learn how to store and retrieve local, roaming, and temporary app data.

segment.source: Store and retrieve settings and other app data
segment.target: Store and retrieve settings and other app data

segment.source: Store and retrieve settings and other app data
segment.target: Store and retrieve settings and other app data

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: App data is mutable data that is specific to a particular app.
segment.target: App data is mutable data that is specific to a particular app.

segment.source: It includes runtime state, user preferences, and other settings.
segment.target: It includes runtime state, user preferences, and other settings.

segment.source: App data is different from user data, data that the user creates and manages when using an app.
segment.target: App data is different from user data, data that the user creates and manages when using an app.

segment.source: User data includes document or media files, email or communication transcripts, or database records holding content created by the user.
segment.target: User data includes document or media files, email or communication transcripts, or database records holding content created by the user.

segment.source: User data may be useful or meaningful to more than one app.
segment.target: User data may be useful or meaningful to more than one app.

segment.source: Often, this is data that the user wants to manipulate or transmit as an entity independent of the app itself, such as a document.
segment.target: Often, this is data that the user wants to manipulate or transmit as an entity independent of the app itself, such as a document.

segment.source: Important note about app data: The lifetime of the app data is tied to the lifetime of the app.
segment.target: Important note about app data: The lifetime of the app data is tied to the lifetime of the app.

segment.source: If the app is removed, all of the app data will be lost as a consequence.
segment.target: If the app is removed, all of the app data will be lost as a consequence.

segment.source: Don't use app data to store user data or anything that users might perceive as valuable and irreplaceable.
segment.target: Don't use app data to store user data or anything that users might perceive as valuable and irreplaceable.

segment.source: We recommend that the user's libraries and Microsoft OneDrive be used to store this sort of information.
segment.target: We recommend that the user's libraries and Microsoft OneDrive be used to store this sort of information.

segment.source: App data is ideal for storing app-specific user preferences, settings, and favorites.
segment.target: App data is ideal for storing app-specific user preferences, settings, and favorites.

segment.source: Types of app data
segment.target: Types of app data

segment.source: There are two types of app data: settings and files.
segment.target: There are two types of app data: settings and files.

segment.source: Settings
segment.target: Settings

segment.source: Use settings to store user preferences and application state info.
segment.target: Use settings to store user preferences and application state info.

segment.source: The app data API enables you to easily create and retrieve settings (we'll show you some examples later in this article).
segment.target: The app data API enables you to easily create and retrieve settings (we'll show you some examples later in this article).

segment.source: Here are data types you can use for app settings:
segment.target: Here are data types you can use for app settings:

segment.source: UInt8, Int16, UInt16, Int32, UInt32, Int64, UInt64, Single, Double
segment.target: UInt8, Int16, UInt16, Int32, UInt32, Int64, UInt64, Single, Double

segment.source: Boolean
segment.target: Boolean

segment.source: Char16, String
segment.target: Char16, String

segment.source: DateTime, TimeSpan
segment.target: DateTime, TimeSpan

segment.source: GUID, Point, Size, Rect
segment.target: GUID, Point, Size, Rect

segment.source: ApplicationDataCompositeValue: A set of related app settings that must be serialized and deserialized atomically.
segment.target: ApplicationDataCompositeValue: A set of related app settings that must be serialized and deserialized atomically.

segment.source: Use composite settings to easily handle atomic updates of interdependent settings.
segment.target: Use composite settings to easily handle atomic updates of interdependent settings.

segment.source: The system ensures the integrity of composite settings during concurrent access and roaming.
segment.target: The system ensures the integrity of composite settings during concurrent access and roaming.

segment.source: Composite settings are optimized for small amounts of data, and performance can be poor if you use them for large data sets.
segment.target: Composite settings are optimized for small amounts of data, and performance can be poor if you use them for large data sets.

segment.source: Files
segment.target: Files

segment.source: Use files to store binary data or to enable your own, customized serialized types.
segment.target: Use files to store binary data or to enable your own, customized serialized types.

segment.source: Storing app data in the app data stores
segment.target: Storing app data in the app data stores

segment.source: When an app is installed, the system gives it its own per-user data stores for settings and files.
segment.target: When an app is installed, the system gives it its own per-user data stores for settings and files.

segment.source: You don't need to know where or how this data exists, because the system is responsible for managing the physical storage, ensuring that the data is kept isolated from other apps and other users.
segment.target: You don't need to know where or how this data exists, because the system is responsible for managing the physical storage, ensuring that the data is kept isolated from other apps and other users.

segment.source: The system also preserves the contents of these data stores when the user installs an update to your app and removes the contents of these data stores completely and cleanly when your app is uninstalled.
segment.target: The system also preserves the contents of these data stores when the user installs an update to your app and removes the contents of these data stores completely and cleanly when your app is uninstalled.

segment.source: Within its app data store, each app has system-defined root directories: one for local files, one for roaming files, and one for temporary files.
segment.target: Within its app data store, each app has system-defined root directories: one for local files, one for roaming files, and one for temporary files.

segment.source: Your app can add new files and new containers to each of these root directories.
segment.target: Your app can add new files and new containers to each of these root directories.

segment.source: Local app data
segment.target: Local app data

segment.source: Local app data should be used for any information that needs to be preserved between app sessions and is not suitable for roaming app data.
segment.target: Local app data should be used for any information that needs to be preserved between app sessions and is not suitable for roaming app data.

segment.source: Data that is not applicable on other devices should be stored here as well.
segment.target: Data that is not applicable on other devices should be stored here as well.

segment.source: There is no general size restriction on local data stored.
segment.target: There is no general size restriction on local data stored.

segment.source: Use the local app data store for data that it does not make sense to roam and for large data sets.
segment.target: Use the local app data store for data that it does not make sense to roam and for large data sets.

segment.source: Retrieve the local app data store
segment.target: Retrieve the local app data store

segment.source: Before you can read or write local app data, you must retrieve the local app data store.
segment.target: Before you can read or write local app data, you must retrieve the local app data store.

segment.source: To retrieve the local app data store, use the ApplicationData.LocalSettings property to get the app's local settings as an ApplicationDataContainer object.
segment.target: To retrieve the local app data store, use the ApplicationData.LocalSettings property to get the app's local settings as an ApplicationDataContainer object.

segment.source: Use the ApplicationData.LocalFolder property to get the files in a StorageFolder object.
segment.target: Use the ApplicationData.LocalFolder property to get the files in a StorageFolder object.

segment.source: Use the ApplicationData.LocalCacheFolder property to get the folder in the local app data store where you can save files that are not included in backup and restore.
segment.target: Use the ApplicationData.LocalCacheFolder property to get the folder in the local app data store where you can save files that are not included in backup and restore.

segment.source: Create and retrieve a simple local setting
segment.target: Create and retrieve a simple local setting

segment.source: To create or write a setting, use the ApplicationDataContainer.Values property to access the settings in the container we got in the previous step.
segment.target: To create or write a setting, use the ApplicationDataContainer.Values property to access the settings in the container we got in the previous step.

segment.source: This example creates a setting named .
segment.target: This example creates a setting named .

segment.source: To retrieve the setting, you use the same ApplicationDataContainer.Values property that you used to create the setting.
segment.target: To retrieve the setting, you use the same ApplicationDataContainer.Values property that you used to create the setting.

segment.source: This example shows how to retrieve the setting we just created.
segment.target: This example shows how to retrieve the setting we just created.

segment.source: Create and retrieve a local composite value
segment.target: Create and retrieve a local composite value

segment.source: To create or write a composite value, create an ApplicationDataCompositeValue object.
segment.target: To create or write a composite value, create an ApplicationDataCompositeValue object.

segment.source: This example creates a composite setting named and adds it to the container.
segment.target: This example creates a composite setting named and adds it to the container.

segment.source: This example shows how to retrieve the composite value we just created.
segment.target: This example shows how to retrieve the composite value we just created.

segment.source: Create and read a local file
segment.target: Create and read a local file

segment.source: To create and update a file in the local app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.CreateFileAsync and Windows.Storage.FileIO.WriteTextAsync.
segment.target: To create and update a file in the local app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.CreateFileAsync and Windows.Storage.FileIO.WriteTextAsync.

segment.source: This example creates a file named in the container and writes the current date and time to the file.
segment.target: This example creates a file named in the container and writes the current date and time to the file.

segment.source: The ReplaceExisting value from the CreationCollisionOption enumeration indicates to replace the file if it already exists.
segment.target: The ReplaceExisting value from the CreationCollisionOption enumeration indicates to replace the file if it already exists.

segment.source: To open and read a file in the local app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFileAsync, Windows.Storage.StorageFile.GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync, and Windows.Storage.FileIO.ReadTextAsync.
segment.target: To open and read a file in the local app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFileAsync, Windows.Storage.StorageFile.GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync, and Windows.Storage.FileIO.ReadTextAsync.

segment.source: This example opens the file created in the previous step and reads the date from the file.
segment.target: This example opens the file created in the previous step and reads the date from the file.

segment.source: For details on loading file resources from various locations, see How to load file resources.
segment.target: For details on loading file resources from various locations, see How to load file resources.

segment.source: Roaming data
segment.target: Roaming data

segment.source: If you use roaming data in your app, your users can easily keep your app's app data in sync across multiple devices.
segment.target: If you use roaming data in your app, your users can easily keep your app's app data in sync across multiple devices.

segment.source: If a user installs your app on multiple devices, the OS keeps the app data in sync, reducing the amount of setup work that the user needs to do for your app on their second device.
segment.target: If a user installs your app on multiple devices, the OS keeps the app data in sync, reducing the amount of setup work that the user needs to do for your app on their second device.

segment.source: Roaming also enables your users to continue a task, such as composing a list, right where they left off even on a different device.
segment.target: Roaming also enables your users to continue a task, such as composing a list, right where they left off even on a different device.

segment.source: The OS replicates roaming data to the cloud when it is updated, and synchronizes the data to the other devices on which the app is installed.
segment.target: The OS replicates roaming data to the cloud when it is updated, and synchronizes the data to the other devices on which the app is installed.

segment.source: The OS limits the size of the app data that each app may roam.
segment.target: The OS limits the size of the app data that each app may roam.

segment.source: See ApplicationData.RoamingStorageQuota.
segment.target: See ApplicationData.RoamingStorageQuota.

segment.source: If the app hits this limit, none of the app's app data will be replicated to the cloud until the app's total roamed app data is less than the limit again.
segment.target: If the app hits this limit, none of the app's app data will be replicated to the cloud until the app's total roamed app data is less than the limit again.

segment.source: For this reason, it is a best practice to use roaming data only for user preferences, links, and small data files.
segment.target: For this reason, it is a best practice to use roaming data only for user preferences, links, and small data files.

segment.source: Roaming data for an app is available in the cloud as long as it is accessed by the user from some device within the required time interval.
segment.target: Roaming data for an app is available in the cloud as long as it is accessed by the user from some device within the required time interval.

segment.source: If the user does not run an app for longer than this time interval, its roaming data is removed from the cloud.
segment.target: If the user does not run an app for longer than this time interval, its roaming data is removed from the cloud.

segment.source: If a user uninstalls an app, its roaming data isn't automatically removed from the cloud, it's preserved.
segment.target: If a user uninstalls an app, its roaming data isn't automatically removed from the cloud, it's preserved.

segment.source: If the user reinstalls the app within the time interval, the roaming data is synchronized from the cloud.
segment.target: If the user reinstalls the app within the time interval, the roaming data is synchronized from the cloud.

segment.source: Register to receive notification when roaming data changes
segment.target: Register to receive notification when roaming data changes

segment.source: To use roaming app data, you need to register for roaming data changes and retrieve the roaming data containers so you can read and write settings.
segment.target: To use roaming app data, you need to register for roaming data changes and retrieve the roaming data containers so you can read and write settings.

segment.source: Register to receive notification when roaming data changes.
segment.target: Register to receive notification when roaming data changes.

segment.source: The DataChanged event notifies you when roaming data changes.
segment.target: The DataChanged event notifies you when roaming data changes.

segment.source: This example sets as the handler for roaming data changes.
segment.target: This example sets as the handler for roaming data changes.

segment.source: Get the containers for the app's settings and files.
segment.target: Get the containers for the app's settings and files.

segment.source: Use the ApplicationData.RoamingSettings property to get the settings and the ApplicationData.RoamingFolder property to get the files.
segment.target: Use the ApplicationData.RoamingSettings property to get the settings and the ApplicationData.RoamingFolder property to get the files.

segment.source: Create and retrieve roaming settings
segment.target: Create and retrieve roaming settings

segment.source: Use the ApplicationDataContainer.Values property to access the settings in the container we got in the previous section.
segment.target: Use the ApplicationDataContainer.Values property to access the settings in the container we got in the previous section.

segment.source: This example creates a simple setting named and a composite value named .
segment.target: This example creates a simple setting named and a composite value named .

segment.source: This example retrieves the settings we just created.
segment.target: This example retrieves the settings we just created.

segment.source: Create and retrieve roaming files
segment.target: Create and retrieve roaming files

segment.source: To create and update a file in the roaming app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.CreateFileAsync and Windows.Storage.FileIO.WriteTextAsync.
segment.target: To create and update a file in the roaming app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.CreateFileAsync and Windows.Storage.FileIO.WriteTextAsync.

segment.source: This example creates a file named in the container and writes the current date and time to the file.
segment.target: This example creates a file named in the container and writes the current date and time to the file.

segment.source: The ReplaceExisting value from the CreationCollisionOption enumeration indicates to replace the file if it already exists.
segment.target: The ReplaceExisting value from the CreationCollisionOption enumeration indicates to replace the file if it already exists.

segment.source: To open and read a file in the roaming app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFileAsync, Windows.Storage.StorageFile.GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync, and Windows.Storage.FileIO.ReadTextAsync.
segment.target: To open and read a file in the roaming app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFileAsync, Windows.Storage.StorageFile.GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync, and Windows.Storage.FileIO.ReadTextAsync.

segment.source: This example opens the file created in the previous section and reads the date from the file.
segment.target: This example opens the file created in the previous section and reads the date from the file.

segment.target: For details on loading file resources from various locations, see How to load file resources.

segment.source: Temporary app data
segment.target: Temporary app data

segment.source: The temporary app data store works like a cache.
segment.target: The temporary app data store works like a cache.

segment.source: Its files do not roam and could be removed at any time.
segment.target: Its files do not roam and could be removed at any time.

segment.source: The System Maintenance task can automatically delete data stored at this location at any time.
segment.target: The System Maintenance task can automatically delete data stored at this location at any time.

segment.source: The user can also clear files from the temporary data store using Disk Cleanup.
segment.target: The user can also clear files from the temporary data store using Disk Cleanup.

segment.source: Temporary app data can be used for storing temporary information during an app session.
segment.target: Temporary app data can be used for storing temporary information during an app session.

segment.source: There is no guarantee that this data will persist beyond the end of the app session as the system might reclaim the used space if needed.
segment.target: There is no guarantee that this data will persist beyond the end of the app session as the system might reclaim the used space if needed.

segment.source: The location is available via the temporaryFolder property.
segment.target: The location is available via the temporaryFolder property.

segment.source: Retrieve the temporary data container
segment.target: Retrieve the temporary data container

segment.source: Use the ApplicationData.TemporaryFolder property to get the files.
segment.target: Use the ApplicationData.TemporaryFolder property to get the files.

segment.source: The next steps use the variable from this step.
segment.target: The next steps use the variable from this step.

segment.source: Create and read temporary files
segment.target: Create and read temporary files

segment.source: To create and update a file in the temporary app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.CreateFileAsync and Windows.Storage.FileIO.WriteTextAsync.
segment.target: To create and update a file in the temporary app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.CreateFileAsync and Windows.Storage.FileIO.WriteTextAsync.

segment.source: This example creates a file named in the container and writes the current date and time to the file.
segment.target: This example creates a file named in the container and writes the current date and time to the file.

segment.source: The ReplaceExisting value from the CreationCollisionOption enumeration indicates to replace the file if it already exists.
segment.target: The ReplaceExisting value from the CreationCollisionOption enumeration indicates to replace the file if it already exists.

segment.source: To open and read a file in the temporary app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFileAsync, Windows.Storage.StorageFile.GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync, and Windows.Storage.FileIO.ReadTextAsync.
segment.target: To open and read a file in the temporary app data store, use the file APIs, such as Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFileAsync, Windows.Storage.StorageFile.GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync, and Windows.Storage.FileIO.ReadTextAsync.

segment.source: Organize app data with containers
segment.target: Organize app data with containers

segment.source: To help you organize your app data settings and files, you create containers (represented by ApplicationDataContainer objects) instead of working directly with directories.
segment.target: To help you organize your app data settings and files, you create containers (represented by ApplicationDataContainer objects) instead of working directly with directories.

segment.source: You can add containers to the local, roaming, and temporary app data stores.
segment.target: You can add containers to the local, roaming, and temporary app data stores.

segment.source: Containers can be nested up to 32 levels deep.
segment.target: Containers can be nested up to 32 levels deep.

segment.source: To create a settings container, call the ApplicationDataContainer.CreateContainer method.
segment.target: To create a settings container, call the ApplicationDataContainer.CreateContainer method.

segment.source: This example creates a local settings container named and adds a setting named .
segment.target: This example creates a local settings container named and adds a setting named .

segment.source: The Always value from the ApplicationDataCreateDisposition enumeration indicates that the container is created if it doesn't already exist.
segment.target: The Always value from the ApplicationDataCreateDisposition enumeration indicates that the container is created if it doesn't already exist.

segment.source: Delete app settings and containers
segment.target: Delete app settings and containers

segment.source: To delete a simple setting that your app no longer needs, use the ApplicationDataContainerSettings.Remove method.
segment.target: To delete a simple setting that your app no longer needs, use the ApplicationDataContainerSettings.Remove method.

segment.source: This example deletesthe local setting that we created earlier.
segment.target: This example deletesthe local setting that we created earlier.

segment.source: To delete a composite setting, use the ApplicationDataCompositeValue.Remove method.
segment.target: To delete a composite setting, use the ApplicationDataCompositeValue.Remove method.

segment.source: This example deletes the local composite setting we created in an earlier example.
segment.target: This example deletes the local composite setting we created in an earlier example.

segment.source: To delete a container, call the ApplicationDataContainer.DeleteContainer method.
segment.target: To delete a container, call the ApplicationDataContainer.DeleteContainer method.

segment.source: This example deletes the local settings container we created earlier.
segment.target: This example deletes the local settings container we created earlier.

segment.source: Versioning your app data
segment.target: Versioning your app data

segment.source: You can optionally version the app data for your app.
segment.target: You can optionally version the app data for your app.

segment.source: This would enable you to create a future version of your app that changes the format of its app data without causing compatibility problems with the previous version of your app.
segment.target: This would enable you to create a future version of your app that changes the format of its app data without causing compatibility problems with the previous version of your app.

segment.source: The app checks the version of the app data in the data store, and if the version is less than the version the app expects, the app should update the app data to the new format and update the version.
segment.target: The app checks the version of the app data in the data store, and if the version is less than the version the app expects, the app should update the app data to the new format and update the version.

segment.source: For more info, see theApplication.Version property and the ApplicationData.SetVersionAsync method.
segment.target: For more info, see theApplication.Version property and the ApplicationData.SetVersionAsync method.
